items.content_html:
Description

Included an example of how to invoke the default hasinstance implementation. I expect it to be a common use case to augment existing behavior and thus it being useful to see how to invoke the existing method.

Motivation

Found it difficult to invoke the original hasInstance symbol myself. I could not find clear documentation on the default value of the symbol to understand how to invoke the default function.

I had to dive into the spec to see that the default implementation from the Function prototype operates on the this context as the class to compare against: https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/fundamental-objects.html#sec-function.prototype-@@hasinstance

I created an example that shows what I expect to be a common use-case. Modifying the instanceof behavior of an existing class to invoke the original behavior in addition to augmenting it with a custom capability.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Update hasinstance example to show invocation

items.content_html:
Description

This PR is part of a multi-PR series that aims to document the WebGPU API. The interfaces documented in this PR are:

  • GPUCommandBuffer (done)
  • GPUCommandEncoder
  • GPUComputePassEncoder
  • GPUQueue(done)
  • GPURenderBundle
  • GPURenderBundleEncoder
  • GPURenderPassEncoder

Note that the main PR for this series is #24202 — that one must be merged first, before this one! after that one is merged, main should be merged into this PR, and the documentation integrity must be checked (e.g. do all the links work) before merging.

You can see full details of the additions expected in the WebGPU docs in my research document.

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: WebGPU PR #5 — Interfaces for handling command encoding and submission

items.content_html:
Part of openwebdocs/project#152

  1. HTMLElement.style did not match the page's modern style, and the example was wrong.
  2. SVGElement.style was missing. Added.
  3. The page linked to CSS Properties Reference was removed. The new page doesn't have the information to convert a CSS property name into a JS identifier, so I added it. (in both pages)

I tested both examples via a temporary {{EmbedLiveSample}} macro. I didn't keep it: the interesting part is on the console anyway (and very long).

In the future, there may be a MathMLElement.style.
items.title: Update documentation for {HTML,SVG}Element.style

items.content_html:
Description

The comment in the code example mentioned only "1" or "0" as possible return values, although "unspecified" is also possible.

Motivation

The code example might trick readers into thinking that only those two values can be returned.

Description

Added missing page for the prefers-reduced-transparency media query (similar to prefers-reduced-motion, etc).

items.content_html:
This does an update of Using readable streams to include a section on how to use the for await...of syntax with fetch(). It is intended to be a bit more of a real world example to complement the section added in ReadableStream.

I've put a couple of notes inline about what I'm trying to achieve, so that you can help me decide if it is reasonable approach.

This is concluding work for #23678
items.title: FF110 Using ReadableStream with async iteration

items.content_html:
Description

This PR is a step towards standardizing our Date docs. I expect to never touch these docs again with Temporal being standardized soon. This is a big-ish PR, it does the following:

  1. Added some overview of various date-related concepts
  2. Made all date component-related pages as consistent as possible
  3. Added mention about NaN timestamps and invalid dates to every page
  4. Standardized the notion of "epoch" to the spec terms: "midnight at the beginning of January 1, 1970, UTC" (with some changes so it follows American norms)
  5. Other general page structure improvements

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Improve Date (1): timestamps & date components

items.content_html:
Description

  • Fix wording — the problem with btoa has nothing to do with either ASCII or UTF-16 — it's because it's capped at characters whose codepoints fit inside 1 byte, so the maximum codepoint it handles is 0xff. ASCII only covers codepoints up to 0x7f, while UTF-16 only starts causing problems after codepoint 0xffff
  • Add much simpler UTF-8 Base64 functions based on TextEncoder and TextDecoder
  • Rearrange solutions in order of usefulness. Tbh I'm not sure it's even worth including the "encode first" solutions, as they aren't standard Base64 and wouldn't be interoperable with systems that expect Base64... but I've left them there for now

Motivation

Fix outdated/incorrect info

Additional details

N/A

Related issues and pull requests

N/A
items.title: Update info about Base64 and Unicode

items.content_html:
Description

This PR offers a minor edit pass to the web app manifest page. It was a bit outdated and I thought could be made more current and clearer.

This PR also contains ref docs for file_handlers which is a manifest member that allows installed PWAs to become handlers for files at the operating system level.

Motivation

This is part of the parent PWA docs revamp project: mdn/mdn#280

In this project, we're rewriting the PWA docs entirely. And part of it is to make sure the manifest ref docs are correct too.

Additional details

For more information about file_handlers:

  • Docs
    • https://developer.chrome.com/articles/file-handling/
    • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/progressive-web-apps-chromium/how-to/handle-files
  • Feature tracking
    • https://chromestatus.com/feature/5721776357113856

Related issues and pull requests

We need this BCD PR to be merged too: mdn/browser-compat-data#19096
items.title: Update web app manifest page and add missing `file_handlers` member

items.content_html:
Description

Added notes concerning the fact that, depending on the underlying OS, "prefers-reduced-motion" does not mean reduced motion, but instead removed/disabled all animations, not specific to motion.

Motivation

The existing article does not consider that fact that some systems and users don't indicate preference for reduced motion, but actually removed animations.
items.title: Clarify OS dependent user preference meaning
